Award.AwardTitle: When Did Quiescent Galaxies First Appear and What Quenched Their Star-Formation?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Galaxies are vast collections of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter, and come in various sizes, shapes, and colors. Understanding how the different types of galaxies formed is one of the major quests in astrophysics. Today, the biggest and heaviest galaxies in the local universe are found to be quiescent (i.e., not forming new stars) and made of very old stars, with typical ages of 12 billion years. To understand how these nearby galaxies formed, their counterparts in the distant, young universe need to be studied as well. Dr. Marchesini and his team will investigate quiescent galaxies over 95% of cosmic history using the highest quality astronomical observations. The findings will be compared with theoretical predictions, providing new clues on what switches off star formation in the early phase of galaxy formation.

Besides training graduate and undergraduate students, Dr. Marchesini will implement a summer research program for high-school students, contribute to the professional development of K-12 science teachers, and deliver public lectures.

The project includes construction of multi-wavelength photometric catalogs of galaxies using data from the Hubble Frontier Fields, ground-based telescopes (Keck and VLT), and Spitzer-IRAC. The spectral energy distributions of the detected galaxies will be modeled to derive photometric redshifts and stellar population properties. The evolution of the stellar mass function of galaxies since redshift z=7 will be measured, with particular emphasis on the quiescent galaxy population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Marchesini and his research group used the constructed multi-wavelength photometric catalogs of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) and the UltraVISTA DR3 surveys to study distant galaxies and to compare the findings with predictions from galaxy formation models, providing feedback to improve the prescriptions for the physical processes responsible for shaping galaxies over cosmic time. As part of the construction of the aforementioned catalogs, mega-deep near-infrared data in the HFF were obtained using the Keck and VLT telescopes, reduced, and publicly released.  Dr. Marchesini and his research group constructed and publicly released multi-wavelength photometric catalogs and catalogs of photometric redshifts, lensing magnification factors, and stellar population properties in the 12 cluster+parallel pointings of the HFF as part of the HFF-DeepSpace program (http://cosmos.phy.tufts.edu/~danilo/HFF/Home.html).

The awarded program resulted in seven published papers. Specifically, two papers presented and accompanied the public releases of the mega-deep near-infrared data and the HFF-DeepSpace catalogs. Tufts University graduate student Nick Martis published a paper presenting the measurements of the evolution with cosmic time of the fraction of quiescent, unobscured and dust-obscured star-forming galaxies as a function of stellar mass over the last 11.5 billion years of cosmic history, finding that dusty star-forming galaxies are the most dominant type of galaxies among the massive galaxy population in the first 4 billion years of cosmic history. Nick Martis published a second paper presenting the findings of a detailed study to characterize the stellar and dust properties of a complete sample of dusty and massive distant galaxies using the combination of the UltraVISTA DR3 multi-wavelength photometric catalog with the infrared fluxes from the Herschel space telescope. Among the several intriguing results presented in this paper, he found a significant population of dusty and massive galaxies with suppressed star-formation activity, but with significant infrared emission. This infrared emission appears dominated by emission from dust heated by evolved stellar populations rather than active star-formation activity. Nick Martis also showed that the typically adopted technique of estimating the level of star-formation activity in distant galaxies tend to over-estimate the level of star-formation activity by a factor of few to several in galaxies with small levels of star-formation activity, result that has important implications for the characterization of the population of massive galaxies in the early universe. The constructed HFF-DeepSpace catalogs were used to study the stellar properties of a very distant multiply imaged galaxy lensed by a foreground cluster which was also observed with the Large Millimeter Telescope. The paper, led by Dr. Alex Pope, presents one of the very few galaxies detected in dust emission at the low mass end, and it shows, remarkably, signs of both low chemical composition and high dust content, challenging our picture of dust production in the early universe. Dr. Marchesini and his research group contributed to two papers led by Dr. Allison Hill, which presented the investigations of the mass, color, structural evolution, and assembly and formation ages of today's massive galaxies over the last 12.3 billion years of cosmic history. These findings were compared to the predictions from simulations of galaxy formation and evolution.

Daniel Lange-Vagle, research technician, led the construction of a new web interface, called "HFF-Explorer", to navigate and explore the images and the high-level products (e.g., catalogs) delivered by the HFF-DeepSpace program. HFF-Explorer is publicly available at: http://cosmos.phy.tufts.edu/~danilo/HFF/HFFexplorer.html

Dr. Marchesini trained and contributed to the professional development of two Ph.D. students (Nick Martis and Kalina Nedkova), a postdoctoral associate (Dr. Heath Shipley), nine undergraduate students (Mitchell Black, Adina Feinstein, Danielle Golub, Justin Hudson, Erin Kado-Fong, James McDowell, Evan Solomonides, Victor Soto Castro, and Theodore Pena), and a high-school student (Matthew Monsalve). Of these students, three are from the under-represented latino community, and three are women.

Dr. Marchesini contributed to the development of STEM K-12 teachers through the Workshops in Space Exploration, which was led by Dr. Waller (physics and astronomy teacher at Rockport High School, and former faculty member of the Physics and Astronomy Department at Tufts University) during the summers. This activity-rich workshop introduced K-12 teachers to the content, structure, and 13.8 Gyr history of the Cosmos.

Finally, Dr. Marchesini has continued to enhance active learning and critical thinking in his undergraduate courses, and strengthen participation in research of undergraduates (especially from under-represented groups).
